game:ancienttools-quickstart-text:
Ancient Tools Guide
Mortar and Pestle The classic mortar and pestle. These two tools have been in use in some form since the Paleolithic era for grinding substances such as spices and oats. To use these items in Vintage Story you must first craft each. Place the mortar on the ground then insert the pestle with . Insert any grindable item with then crouch and hold to begin grinding away! Adze This adze, introduced in the Neolithic era, was a tool commonly used by ancient carpenters to shape wood into various objects or architecture. In its current implementation in the Ancient Tools mod, the adze is used to strip bark from trees. To create an adze, an adze head must first be created either through stone knapping, smelting or smithing. Craft the resulting adze head with a stick and you'll now have yourself a handy tool for collecting bark! Approach the nearest tree with adze in hand then crouch and hold to begin stripping away. Stone adze heads can also be crafted with bone for an extra sturdy tool! The tree bark that you collect can be used for a variety of different purposes. Bark can make for an excellent firestarter in place of firewood. Or, it can be woven to create cute little bark baskets to place things in. Birch bark and pine bark are a special arboreal resource in that they possess some unique properties that we can take advantage of. The inner layer of bark from either tree is edible can be ground down into a flour that can then be baked into bread. This was a Scandanavian tradition of the indigenous Sami culture. Both varities of bark also have various medicinal properties. Have a look at the salve preparation guide if you're interested in taking advantage of them! Curing Rack Curing meats with salt is a centuries-old practice of preservation. This requires a carefully controlled environment to ensure the meat doesn't rot before the meat is cured. A cellar is recommended! A curing rack can be equipped with two hooks with . Hang any variety of salted meat(redmeat,poultry,bushmeat) and wait until your delicious meat is perfectly cured! Salted meats can also be cooked in a firepit for a quick meal solution. Native American Tanning Pre-contact Native American cultures used a different technique for tanning animal hides than colonial European settlers to create their iconic leather products. Ancient Tools implements a simplified version of this technique to give you another means of crafting leather! Want to give it a try? Visit the Native American Tanning Guide. Pitch Pitch is a sticky black substance produced by combining then melting finely powdered charcoal, tree resin, and various fibrous materials such as dry grass or dried animal feces. This material is exceptionally waterproof and sticky. Historically, it has been used to caulk the seams of wooden sailing vessels or to seal containers, such as food crocks. Ancient Tools takes advantage of its waterproof property by allowing you to use firepits, pit kilns, and forges exposed to the elements whenever pitch is used as the fuel. Additionally, pitch can be used to create long-lasting, brightly burning torches that won't be extinguished by rain. It can also be used to create chambersticks as a permenant lighting solution similar to oil lamps. A detailed explanation of how to produce pitch can be found in the Pitch Guide. Note: Since resin is so integral to Ancient Tools pitch production, a system has been implemented that allows knives to scrape pine and acacia trees to create leaking logs. This system can be disabled in the mod config files.
game:ancienttools-quickstart-text-salve:
Ancient Tools Salve Creation Guide
Tree bark has had many various uses throughout history. Many trees, such as birch and pine, have various beneficial healing properties. Birch is most commonly used to ease joint pain, whilst pine is most commonly used to reduce inflammation. Salves are sometimes created by homesteaders then applied to the skin to take advantage of these properties. To create a salve with Ancient Tools, first, you must convert two cooking pots into empty salve containers. This can be done by crouching then pressing with a salve ingredient(birch/pine bark, fat, or beeswax) or by crafting a cooking pot in the grid with a medicinal bark. Place both empty containers on the ground. Fill one with birchORpine bark and fat, then the other with beeswax. Heat both in a firepit to convert them to prepared versions. Finally, place one prepared container on the ground then crouch and hold with the other container in hand to pour them together. Congratulations, you made a healing salve! the finished salve to extract a portion that will heal over time when used. Empty salve containers can be placed in the crafting grid to convert them back into cooking pots.
game:ancienttools-quickstart-text-tannin:
Native American Tanning Guide
Grab your nearest raw hide and let's get started! To make removal of undesirable fleshy bits easier, hides were tied into sacks with the flesh side inward and filled with water to soften the flesh. To do this, simply your hide on a water source or craft a sack using a filled bucket of water. Place the sack on the ground someplace and wait. When it is ready, it will become a soaked hide sack. While waiting it could be useful to craft up a stretching frame in preparation! Simply take the hide when it's ready and stretch it on the frame. Using a trusty knife, crouch and begin scraping away hair, fat and other undesirable materials from the hide using . The next step might sound disgusting, but it's essential to create a soft, pliable leather. We need to create a 'braining solution' to soak our hide in. Any animal brain will do. Take the brain and combine it with 10L of water in a barrel to create the solution. Now, take the hide from the stretching frame and seal it in the barrel with the braining solution you just made. This will take some time. When the hide has been thoroughly soaked in solution, the next step is to smoke the hide. This makes the hide water resistant and gives the leather its iconic golden color. Hang your hide over a fire pit and wait for it to become a smoked hide. Now, the final part! Take your smoked hide and, using a knife, carefully cut it into strips of leather. This is performed in the crafting grid.
game:ancienttools-quickstart-text-pitch:
Pitch Guide
Pitch was once a highly saught after resource for its versatility. It could be used as a glue, a sealant, a fuel, and for many other purposes. There was no 'one way' to create pitch. Many different resources were combined for similar results. However, with Ancient Tools, you will need some charcoal, resin, and dry grass on hand for this process. To get started, you must grind two pieces of charcoal into powdered charcoal using a mortar and pestle, or any other means of grinding items. Take one piece of powdered charcoal and interact with a cooking pot using to transform the pot into an empty pitch container. Next, fill up the container using with 2 parts powdered charcoal, 4 parts resin, and 1 part dry grass. When the container is properly filled, it will convert into an unprepared pitch mixture. Now, simply pick up the mixture and heat it in the nearest firepit to create prepared pitch. When it's been finished, you can place the pot on the ground and take pieces of pitch by using a stick.
blockhelp-pour-barkoil: Pour melted wax into bark oil
blockhelp-pour-wax: Pour bark oil into melted wax
blockinfo-curingrack: Typically used to cure salted meat. Hooks not included.
blockinfo-curingrack-no-entity: Something went wrong with this block. The BlockEntity does not exist. Please break the block and place it again.
blockinfo-salve-empty-fillwithbark: A salve container must be filled with birch/pine bark and fat OR beeswax.
blockinfo-salve-empty-crouch: Crouch and insert an item to get started.
blockinfo-salve-mixwithoil: Must be mixed with bark oil to create a healing salve.
blockinfo-salve-mixwithwax: Must be mixed with melted wax to create a healing salve.
blockinfo-pitch-empty: Fill with powdered charcoal, resin, and dry grass to create a pitch mixture.
blockinfo-pitch-insert: Insert an item to get started.
game:handbook-crafting-text-strippedlog: Stripping wood from logs using an adze. Additionally, a stripped log will be returned when an adze is used with a log in the crafting grid.
game:handbook-crafting-text-finishedsalv: Mixing a pot of melted wax with a pot of prepared bark oil in-world to create a finished salve containing multiple portions. Portions can be taken from this salve with .
game:handbook-crafting-text-salveportion: Mixing a pot of melted wax with a pot of prepared bark oil in-world to create a finished salve containing multiple portions. Portions can be taken from this salve with .
game:handbook-crafting-text-pitch: Combining powdered charcoal, resin, and dry grass into an empty pitch container and cooking the resulting mixture on a firepit. Place the prepared pitch on the ground to take individual pitch pieces.

iteminfo-brain-food: Can also be used to cook stews.
